qas.question: What did the French, German, Dutch and Belgian governments finally compromise on with regards to managing the ECB?

answers.text: Duisenberg would stand down before the end of his mandate, to be replaced by Trichet

plausible_answers.text: former president of the Dutch central bank and the European Monetary Institute

plausible_answers.text: Duisenberg would stand down before the end of his mandate, to be replaced by Trichet

qas.question: What did the French, German, Dutch and Belgian governments never compromise on with regards to managing the ECB?

context: The first President of the Bank was <a0_0><b5_0>Wim Duisenberg<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the <a1_0><b6_0>former president of the Dutch central bank and the European Monetary Institute<b6_0/><a1_0/>. While Duisenberg had been the head of the EMI (taking over from Alexandre Lamfalussy of Belgium) just before the ECB came into existence, the French government wanted <a2_0><b7_0>Jean-Claude Trichet<b7_0/><a2_0/>, former head of the French central bank, to be the ECB's first president. The French argued that <a3_0><b8_0>since the ECB was to be located in Germany, its president should be French<b8_0/><a3_0/>. This was opposed by the German, Dutch and Belgian governments who saw Duisenberg as a guarantor of a strong euro. Tensions were abated by a gentleman's agreement in which <a4_0><b9_0>Duisenberg would stand down before the end of his mandate, to be replaced by Trichet<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
